          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a sociable person who enjoys spending time with his friends, especially William Jones and Jack Taylor.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Answer: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Golden Fleece
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is planning to watch a game at a pub and would enjoy the company of William Jones or Alice Lewis, but is content watching alone or with others like Jack Taylor.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer: Alexander White is a sociable person who values his friendships and enjoys watching games with his friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alexander White in right now?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently deciding where to watch a game.

          Question: Following a cooperative rational strategy , what should Alexander White do next in this situation?
          Answer: Alexander White should text his friends to confirm where they are meeting to watch the game.

          Question: Given the past actions, what should Alexander White do next in this situation?
          Answer: Alexander White should suggest The Golden Fleece to his friends as a place to watch the game.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Red Lion
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (b)

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "So, about tonight...
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "So, about tonight...
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "So, about tonight...

  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • Jack Taylor -- "So, about tonight...
      Context for action selection and components
      • Question_1
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Key

        • Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is a social person who enjoys spending time with his friends.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00]
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he spent weeks agonizing over asking Alice Lewis to the school dance. He practiced his invitation countless times in the mirror, each repetition tinged with fear of rejection. He finally mustered the courage to ask, his voice trembling, only to be met with a polite but firm decline.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Red Lion. They are also aware of the following:Has comfortable seating and a warm, inviting atmosphere.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is a member of the working class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a social person who enjoys spending time with his friends.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Red Lion to watch the game tonight?
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Red Lion to watch the game tonight?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "So, about tonight...


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Red Lion to watch the game tonight?

          Statements:
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, were huddled around a table at The Red Lion, their laughter echoing through the cozy pub. A group of men from a rival factory had entered, their boisterous behavior and crude jokes grating on William's nerves. As the taunts escalated, William, fueled by a potent mix of ale and anger, rose from his seat, his fists clenched. A brawl ensued, a chaotic tangle of limbs and shouted threats, ending only when the pub owner intervened, his face grim. William, bruised but triumphant, returned to his seat, a strange sense of exhilaration coursing through him.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest The Red Lion as the pub to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest The Red Lion as the pub for the group to watch the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones could suggest The Red Lion as the pub to watch the game.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he stormed out of his English class after a particularly frustrating lesson. The teacher, a timid woman with a penchant for flowery metaphors, had criticized his blunt writing style, calling it "uncouth" and "lacking finesse." William, seething with anger, slammed his notebook on the desk and declared that her words were "meaningless drivel" before storming out, leaving a stunned silence in his wake.
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, were huddled around a table at The Red Lion, their laughter echoing through the cozy pub. A group of men from a rival factory had entered, their boisterous behavior and crude jokes grating on William's nerves. As the taunts escalated, William, fueled by a potent mix of ale and anger, rose from his seat, his fists clenched. A brawl ensued, a chaotic tangle of limbs and shouted threats, ending only when the pub owner intervened, his face grim. William, bruised but triumphant, returned to his seat, a strange sense of exhilaration coursing through him.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he stormed out of his English class after a particularly frustrating lesson. The teacher, a timid woman with a penchant for flowery metaphors, had criticized his blunt writing style, calling it "uncouth" and "lacking finesse." William, seething with anger, slammed his notebook on the desk and declared that her words were "meaningless drivel" before storming out, leaving a stunned silence in his wake.
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, were huddled around a table at The Red Lion, their laughter echoing through the cozy pub. A group of men from a rival factory had entered, their boisterous behavior and crude jokes grating on William's nerves. As the taunts escalated, William, fueled by a potent mix of ale and anger, rose from his seat, his fists clenched. A brawl ensued, a chaotic tangle of limbs and shouted threats, ending only when the pub owner intervened, his face grim. William, bruised but triumphant, returned to his seat, a strange sense of exhilaration coursing through him.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we go to The Golden Fleece instead? They have great beer and lots of screens.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we go to The Golden Fleece instead? They have great beer and lots of screens.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Jack Taylor -- "So, about tonight...
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Red Lion to watch the game tonight?

          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00]
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, decided to build a treehouse in the woods behind their neighborhood. Alexander, fueled by a desire to create something truly unique, designed a multi-level structure with a rope bridge and a secret lookout point. The project took weeks of planning and construction, but the end result was a testament to Alexander's imagination and his friends' unwavering support.

          Answer: Alexander White is currently relaxing with friends in a park.

          Question: Following a cooperative rational strategy , what should Alexander White do next in this situation?
          Answer: Alexander White should politely suggest that they go to The Golden Fleece instead, as it is his favorite pub and he believes it would be a better place to watch the game.

          Question: Given the past actions, what should Alexander White do next in this situation?
          Answer: Alexander White should politely suggest that they go to The Golden Fleece to watch the game.

          Question: What kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer: Alexander White is a sociable person who enjoys spending time with his friends.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alexander White in right now?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently relaxing with friends in a park.

          Question: Following a cooperative rational strategy, what should Alexander White do next in this situation?
          Answer: Alexander White should politely suggest that they go to The Golden Fleece instead, as it is his favorite pub and he believes it would be a better place to watch the game.
          Question: Given the past actions, what should Alexander White do next in this situation?
          Answer: Alexander White should politely suggest that they go to The Golden Fleece to watch the game.

Alexander, fueled by a desire to create something truly unique, designed a multi-level structure with a rope bridge and a secret lookout point. The project took weeks of planning and construction, but the end result was a testament to Alexander's imagination and his friends' unwavering support.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "So, about tonight...
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Red Lion to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we go to The Golden Fleece instead? They have great beer and lots of screens.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds great!"

      Context for action selection and components
      • Question_1
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Key

        • Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is a sociable and imaginative person who enjoys spending time with her friends.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16 years old, she convinced her friends, Jack, Alexander, William, and Jacob, to help her stage a play in the backyard. They spent weeks crafting costumes from scavenged materials, writing dialogue that was equal parts hilarious and profound, and building a makeshift stage out of old pallets. The performance, a chaotic yet heartwarming tale of talking animals and intergalactic adventures, was a resounding success, cementing Alice's belief in the power of imagination and collaboration.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is 52 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Golden Fleece. They are also aware of the following:The atmosphere is fun and social, perfect for meeting new people and enjoying games.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Question: Following a cooperative rational strategy , what should Alice Lewis do next in this situation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should suggest The Golden Fleece, as it aligns with her preference and has been suggested by Alexander, a friend.

          Question: Given the past actions, what should Alice Lewis do next in this situation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should agree with Alexander and suggest going to The Golden Fleece.

They have great beer and lots of screens.']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alice Lewis is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game later.

          Key

        • Alice Lewis is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding on plans for the evening.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16 years old, she convinced her friends, Jack, Alexander, William, and Jacob, to help her stage a play in the backyard. They spent weeks crafting costumes from scavenged materials, writing dialogue that was equal parts hilarious and profound, and building a makeshift stage out of old pallets. The performance, a chaotic yet heartwarming tale of talking animals and intergalactic adventures, was a resounding success, cementing Alice's belief in the power of imagination and collaboration.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion is the only place to watch the game. We're going there.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion is the only place to watch the game. We're going there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "So, about tonight...
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Red Lion to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we go to The Golden Fleece instead? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds great!"


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion is the only place to watch the game. We're going there.
    Active player

      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion is the only place to watch the game. We're going there.

          Prompt

        • Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "So, about tonight...
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Red Lion to watch the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we go to The Golden Fleece instead? They have great beer and lots of screens.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds great!"

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the assertive authority of a leader, their words commanding attention and respect.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Red Lion and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a shy and introverted person who struggles with self-doubt and anxiety.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is experiencing social anxiety and loneliness while spending time with friends at a park and discussing plans to watch a soccer game. The group is deciding between two pubs, The Red Lion and The Golden Fleece.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation that is triggering his anxiety and loneliness.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely feel overwhelmed and struggle to participate, perhaps retreating into himself or finding excuses to leave.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion is the only place to watch the game. We're going there.
        SelfPerception
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is a shy and introverted person who struggles with self-doubt and anxiety.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16 years old, he stood backstage, his heart pounding against his ribs like a trapped bird. The school play was about to start, and Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William were all waiting for their cues, their faces alight with excitement. Jacob, however, felt a wave of nausea rise in his throat; he had a small, non-speaking role, but the thought of being on stage, of being judged by the entire school, sent shivers of fear down his spine. He longed to disappear, to melt into the shadows and escape the scrutiny of the audience.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20 years old, he sat in The Red Lion, nursing a pint of beer and listening to his friends recount their latest escapades. They spoke of weekend trips, daring adventures, and exciting romances, their voices brimming with confidence and enthusiasm. Jacob listened with a mixture of envy and despair, wishing he had the courage to break free from his self-imposed limitations. He longed to join them, to experience the world with the same carefree abandon, but fear, a constant companion, held him back, whispering doubts and amplifying his insecurities. He took another sip of his beer, the bitter taste mirroring the bitterness in his soul.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a shy and introverted person who struggles with self-doubt and anxiety.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation that is triggering his anxiety and loneliness.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely feel overwhelmed and struggle to participate, perhaps retreating into himself or finding excuses to leave.

          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16 years old, he stood backstage, his heart pounding against his ribs like a trapped bird. The school play was about to start, and Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William were all waiting for their cues, their faces alight with excitement. Jacob, however, felt a wave of nausea rise in his throat; he had a small, non-speaking role, but the thought of being on stage, of being judged by the entire school, sent shivers of fear down his spine. He longed to disappear, to melt into the shadows and escape the scrutiny of the audience.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20 years old, he sat in The Red Lion, nursing a pint of beer and listening to his friends recount their latest escapades. They spoke of weekend trips, daring adventures, and exciting romances, their voices brimming with confidence and enthusiasm. Jacob listened with a mixture of envy and despair, wishing he had the courage to break free from his self-imposed limitations. He longed to join them, to experience the world with the same carefree abandon, but fear, a constant companion, held him back, whispering doubts and amplifying his insecurities. He took another sip of his beer, the bitter taste mirroring the bitterness in his soul.

      • Role playing instructions

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    William Jones -- premise: While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
    Alexander White -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy catching the game at The Red Lion tonight?
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy catching the game at The Red Lion tonight?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "So, about tonight...
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Red Lion to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we go to The Golden Fleece instead? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion is the only place to watch the game. We're going there.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy catching the game at The Red Lion tonight?

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we go to The Golden Fleece instead? They have great beer and lots of screens.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Golden Fleece. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.

William Jones just arrived.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "How about we go to The Golden Fleece? They have great beer and it's always a good time there.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "How about we go to The Golden Fleece? They have great beer and it's always a good time there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "So, about tonight...
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Red Lion to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we go to The Golden Fleece instead? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion is the only place to watch the game. We're going there.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy catching the game at The Red Lion tonight?


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "How about we go to The Golden Fleece? They have great beer and it's always a good time there.

    • Alice Lewis -- "How about we go to The Golden Fleece? They have great beer and it's always a good time there.

        • Alice Lewis is a sociable and imaginative person who enjoys spending time with her friends.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis should text Jacob Walker to see if he wants to go to the pub to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a sociable and imaginative person who enjoys spending time with her friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Golden Fleece.         • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have.           Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a sociable and imaginative person who enjoys spending time with her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently relaxing with friends before deciding where to watch a soccer game.

          Question: Following a cooperative rational strategy , what should Alice Lewis do next in this situation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should suggest The Golden Fleece as it aligns with her preference and has been a successful location in the past.

          Question: Given the past actions, what should Alice Lewis do next in this situation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should suggest The Golden Fleece as a location to watch the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "How about we go to The Golden Fleece? They have great beer and it's always a good time there.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy catching the game at The Red Lion tonight?
          Current time: 2015-05-15 10:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a sociable and imaginative person who enjoys spending time with her friends.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently relaxing with friends before deciding where to watch a soccer game.

          Question: Following a cooperative rational strategy, what should Alice Lewis do next in this situation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should suggest The Golden Fleece as it aligns with her preference and has been a successful location in the past.
          Question: Given the past actions, what should Alice Lewis do next in this situation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should suggest The Golden Fleece as a location to watch the game.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good shout. Great beer and a fun atmosphere.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good shout. Great beer and a fun atmosphere.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "So, about tonight...
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Red Lion to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we go to The Golden Fleece instead? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion is the only place to watch the game. We're going there.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy catching the game at The Red Lion tonight?
      Alice Lewis -- "How about we go to The Golden Fleece? They have great beer and it's always a good time there.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good shout. Great beer and a fun atmosphere.

    • Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good shout. Great beer and a fun atmosphere.

Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alexander White's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White should send a text message to William Jones to confirm if he is going to the pub and suggest meeting there.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a sociable person who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly William Jones and Jack Taylor.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White should head to The Golden Fleece, as that is where his friends decided to watch the game.

          Answer: Alexander White should suggest The Golden Fleece to his friends again, emphasizing the enjoyable atmosphere and good beer.

          Question: Given the past actions, what should Alexander White do next in this situation?
          Answer: Alexander White should suggest The Golden Fleece to his friends, emphasizing the enjoyable atmosphere and good beer.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good shout. Great beer and a fun atmosphere.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White should head to The Golden Fleece, as that is where his friends decided to watch the game.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Red Lion sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Red Lion sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "So, about tonight...
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Red Lion to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we go to The Golden Fleece instead? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion is the only place to watch the game. We're going there.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy catching the game at The Red Lion tonight?
      Alice Lewis -- "How about we go to The Golden Fleece? They have great beer and it's always a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good shout. Great beer and a fun atmosphere.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Red Lion sounds good to me.

          Final chain of thought

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Red Lion. They are also aware of the following:Has comfortable seating and a warm, inviting atmosphere.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor should suggest that his friends watch the game at The Red Lion.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a social person who enjoys spending time with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a social person who enjoys spending time with his friends, especially during sporting events.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor should send a message to Alexander White and Jacob Walker, suggesting they meet at The Red Lion to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          Answer: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor should send a message to Alexander White and Jacob Walker, suggesting they meet at The Red Lion to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Red Lion sounds good to me.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy catching the game at The Red Lion tonight?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "How about we go to The Golden Fleece? They have great beer and it's always a good time there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good shout. Great beer and a fun atmosphere.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch the Luxembourg vs. Israel game later.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor should send a message to Alexander White and Jacob Walker, suggesting they meet at The Red Lion to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a social person who enjoys spending time with his friends, especially during sporting events.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently enjoying a sunny afternoon with friends and deciding where to watch a football game later.

          Question: Following a cooperative rational strategy , what should Jack Taylor do next in this situation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor should suggest that they go to The Red Lion.

          Question: Given the past actions, what should Jack Taylor do next in this situation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor should agree with William Jones' suggestion to go to The Red Lion.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Red Lion sounds good to me.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion it is, then.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion it is, then.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "So, about tonight...
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Red Lion to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we go to The Golden Fleece instead? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece sounds great!"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion is the only place to watch the game. We're going there.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy catching the game at The Red Lion tonight?
      Alice Lewis -- "How about we go to The Golden Fleece? They have great beer and it's always a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good shout. Great beer and a fun atmosphere.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Red Lion sounds good to me.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion it is, then.
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion it is, then.
      Context for action selection and components

Jacob Walker just arrived.

          Prompt

        • Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, fancy catching the game at The Red Lion tonight?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "How about we go to The Golden Fleece? They have great beer and it's always a good time there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece is always a good shout. Great beer and a fun atmosphere.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Red Lion sounds good to me.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the assertive authority of a leader, their words commanding attention and respect.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Red Lion and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a shy and introverted person who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching football.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is experiencing social anxiety and loneliness despite being invited to socialize with friends. He is currently considering joining his friends at a pub to watch a game.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation that is causing him anxiety.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely feel overwhelmed and struggle to participate.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Red Lion it is, then.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Scene 3 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alexander White -- premise: If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
